questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

 

The patient presents with signs of paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, indicated by the ingestion of a high dose, deranged liver function tests (LFTs), and oliguria. Paracetamol overdose can lead to severe hepatotoxicity and acute liver failure.

 

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity. It works by replenishing glutathione stores, enhancing non-toxic metabolism of paracetamol, and reducing the formation of harmful metabolites. Early administration of N-acetylcysteine significantly reduces the risk of liver damage and improves outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is used in the management of shock to improve renal perfusion and cardiac output. It is not indicated in the treatment of paracetamol toxicity and does not address the underlying hepatic damage.

 

Option C. Ursodeoxycholic acid: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used in the treatment of certain cholestatic liver diseases to improve bile flow. It does not play a role in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload conditions such as heart failure or renal failure. It does not address the hepatotoxicity caused by paracetamol overdose and is not part of the standard treatment protocol for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: A patient presents with complains of numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three and a half fingers, along with numbness at the base of the thumb. Which nerve is most commonly affected in this case? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Median nerve

 

The median nerve originates from the brachial plexus (C5-T1) and supplies sensory and motor innervation to specific regions of the upper limb. Sensory innervation of the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger) on the palmar side, along with the base of the thumb, is provided by the median nerve.

 

The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve supplies sensation to the base of the thumb and The digital cutaneous branches of the median nerve provide sensation to the lateral three and a half fingers.

 

In median nerve compression, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, patients often report numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three fingers. This condition occurs due to entrapment of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel, causing dysfunction in the sensory and motor functions it supplies.

 

Injury or compression of the median nerve at the wrist level spares the palmar cutaneous branch but affects the thumb, index, middle fingers, and part of the ring finger on the palmar aspect, leading to characteristic symptoms of numbness and tingling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the dorsal aspect of the hand and the posterior forearm. It is not responsible for sensation over the lateral three fingers on the palmar side. Radial nerve injury typically causes wrist drop and loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand, not numbness in the fingers.

 

Option B. Anterior Interosseous nerve (AIN): The AIN is a motor branch of the median nerve that does not carry sensory fibers. It supplies deep muscles of the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus (FPL), pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP). AIN syndrome results in motor deficits such as the inability to make an "OK" sign (due to weakness of FPL and FDP), but no sensory loss, making it an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies the medial one and a half fingers (ring finger and little finger) and the hypothenar muscles. Damage to the ulnar nerve would lead to clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers, sensory loss on the medial aspect of the hand, and difficulty with fine motor movements due to intrinsic hand muscle involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers on the palmar side and the base of the thumb. Compression of the median nerve at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome) leads to numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the affected digits without dorsal hand involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amorolfine

 

  • Amorolfine is a morpholine that is available as a 5% nail lacquer. Amorolfine inhibits two separate stages in the synthesis of ergosterol and is fungicidal.
  • It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxiconazole:

  • This is an azole antifungal drug.
  • Azoles work by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in converting lanosterol to ergosterol.

 

Option C. Ciclopirox olamine:

  • Ciclopirox is a hydroxypyridone antifungal agent, not a morpholine.

 

 

  • It acts by chelating polyvalent cations, resulting in the inhibition of the metal-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of peroxides within fungal cells.

 

Option D. Tioconazole:

 

Tioconazole is another azole antifungal agent and, like oxiconazole, works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amorolfine is the only morpholine derivative, used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections.

 

Reference - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 18 Page no 18.12

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20737634/

https://ijdvl.com/onychomycosis-diagnosis-and-management/

questions.text: A young male patient, aged 20, presents with increasing localized pain that developed gradually over time. Imaging via X-ray revealed sunray appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma 

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, accounting for approximately 20% of all cases. 
  • It most commonly occurs in the extremities. 
  • Approximately 75% of patients < 25 years of age; the average at diagnosis is 20 years are affected.
  • High-grade conventional intramedullary osteosarcoma is the most common subtype. 
  • It is a biologically complex and aggressive tumor involving a long bone's metaphysis, usually adjacent to a physis with the most significant growth, such as the proximal humerus, distal femur, or proximal tibia.
  • It has a slightly increased incidence in males than females. 
  • High-grade intramedullary osteosarcoma comprises approximately 80% of all osteosarcomas; 42% occur in the femur, 19% in the tibia, and 10% in the humerus. 
  • Symptoms of may be present for a significant amount of time, sometimes weeks to months, before patients seek evaluation. 
  • Most commonly, the presenting symptom is bone pain, particularly with activity. 
  • A history of traumatic musculoskeletal injury may or may not be reported. 
  • Pain and swelling at the local site, usually at the growing ends of an extremity or long bones, are the most common presenting symptoms. 
  • Physical examination findings include:
    • A palpable, tender mass
    • Decreased range of motion of adjacent joint, with possible effusion
    • Pain on weight-bearing or inability to bear weight
    • Local or regional lymphadenopathy (unusual)
    • Respiratory findings with metastatic forms
  • Radiographs of the conventional osteosarcoma usually demonstrates medullary and cortical bone destruction with mixed lytic and blastic appearance.
  • High-grade osteosarcoma is often described as having a permeative or moth-eaten appearance with a "sunburst" configuration due to aggressive periostitis or "codman triangle" configuration due to elevation of the periosteum away from the bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is an aggressive tumor of adolescents and young adults. It is the second most common primary bone malignancy in adolescents and young adults with a median age of 15 years. Patients often present with local symptoms such as pain, stiffness, or swelling for a few weeks or months. More than 50% of patients have intermittent pain that worsens at night. It is commonly found in the diaphysis of long bones but can occur in different locations with varying presentations. Bone or metastatic lesions within the long bone can present as pathological fractures. The pelvic location of Ewing sarcoma can present as back pain. The presence of systemic symptoms, including fever and weight loss, often indicates metastatic disease. Plain radiographs of the affected area may show destructive confluent '' moth-eaten" lesions, "Codman triangle" of the elevated periosteum, or multilayered "onion-skin" periosteal reaction.

 

 

Option B. Gout: Gout is among the most prevalent etiologies of chronic inflammatory arthritis, characterized by monosodium urate (MSU) monohydrate crystals deposition within tissues. It is characterized biochemically by extracellular fluid urate saturation, which is reflected by hyperuricemia in the blood, with plasma or serum urate concentrations exceeding 6.8 mg/dL. The etiology of is usually multifactorial, including genetic predisposition, medical comorbidities, and dietary factors. Older age and male sex are the common risk factors. The initial manifestation is an acute attack of arthritis, usually monoarticular, marked by the abrupt onset of severe pain and swelling. Maximum inflammation occurs within 12-24 hours. Gout flares are typically monoarticular, with 85-90% occurring in the lower extremities. The first metatarsophalangeal joint is the most commonly involved. The talar, subtalar, ankle, and knee can also be involved. On physical examination, the affected joint is red, swollen, warm, and tender. Tophi, subcutaneous deposits of urate which form nodules, can be found in patients with persistent hyperuricemia. Radiographically, joints show joint effusion (earliest sign), preservation of joint space until late stages of the disease, absence of periarticular osteopenia, eccentric erosions, and “punched-out” erosions with sclerotic margins in a marginal and juxta-articular distribution, with overhanging edges. The bone mineralization is normal. 

 

 

Option D. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilaginous neoplasms that account for 20% of all primary malignant tumors of the bone. They usually arise in the pelvis or long bones. The majority of chondrosarcomas are sporadic, but they may develop from the malignant transformation of osteochondromas and enchondromas. Chondrosarcoma is a tumor of adulthood and older age. The majority of patients are older than 50 years of age, with a slight male predominance. The most common locations of involvement include the axial skeleton (pelvis, scapula, sternum, and ribs) followed by the proximal femur and proximal humerus. Involvement of the hands and feet is rare. Local swelling and pain are the most common presenting symptoms. The symptoms are usually of long duration (months to years). Plain radiography is used for initial evaluation as it allows the identification of the cartilaginous nature and the aggressiveness of the lesion. Plain x-rays may reveal lytic lesions in 50% cases, intralesional calcifications in 70% cases (popcorn calcification or rings and arcs calcification), endosteal scalloping, permeative or moth-eaten appearance in high-grade chondrosarcomas, and cortical remodeling, thickening, and periosteal reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient). 
  • A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.

choices.text: Cannot comment without d-dimer values

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High

 

The Well's Score is a clinical tool used to estimate the probability of a pulmonary embolism (PE). The score is calculated based on various risk factors and clinical features. In this patient's case:

 

Modified wells criteria: 3 + 3 + 1.5 = 7.5 (>4) suggestive of high risk.

 

 

Inference:

 

  • 4: PE Likely
  • < 4: PE unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When assessing the risk of pulmonary embolism, especially in postoperative patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT, it is essential to consider both the clinical presentation and the surgical history. The Wells score is a valuable tool in stratifying the risk and guiding further diagnostic testing and management. In this scenario, the patient falls into a high-risk category, indicating that further immediate investigation, typically with imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram, is warranted.

 

Reference - UpToDate/Wells score

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: An elderly patient complains of multiple clots in his urine. Which catheter should be used in this patient which can facilitate irrigation and clot removal from the urinary bladder? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 22 French Foley's 3 lumen catheter

 

Explanation: 


A triple lumen catheter is ideal for managing clots in bladder as it has:

 

  • First channel for urine drainage
  • Second channel for balloon inflation
  • Third channel specifically for continuous irrigation
  • 22 French size is appropriate for adequate drainage of clots
  • Commonly used after procedures like TURP where post-operative clots are expected
  • Allows simultaneous irrigation and drainage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 22 French Foley's 4 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Does not exist in clinical practice
  • No requirement for fourth lumen

 

Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Has only drainage and balloon inflation channels
  • No separate channel for irrigation
  • Cannot perform continuous irrigation effectively

 

Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel
  • No irrigation capability
  • Inadequate for managing clots
  • Not practical for this clinical scenario

 

Educational Objective: 


A three-way Foley's catheter (22Fr) is the appropriate choice for managing bladder clots as it allows simultaneous drainage and irrigation through separate channels.

questions.text: Which of the following is contra-indicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy because it causes fetal renal hypoplasia or agenesis. This leads to early-onset oligohydramnios due to reduced fetal urine production. Both ACE inhibitors and ARBs (Angiotensin Receptor Blockers) are teratogenic drugs that should not be used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-methyl dopa: Incorrect because it is a safe antihypertensive drug that is safe to use during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Incorrect because it is a calcium channel blocker that can be safely used to treat hypertension during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Incorrect because it is a combined alpha and beta blocker that is considered safe and is commonly used to treat hypertension during pregnancy. It is the drug of choice in hypertension in pregnancy. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

ACE inhibitors and ARBs are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as they cause fetal renal hypoplasia/agenesis leading to oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presented to the clinic and underwent karyotyping. What is the likely diagnosis in the karyotype shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome

 

The karyotype image shows 45 chromosomes with a single X chromosome and no second sex chromosome, confirming a 45, XO karyotype, which is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is a condition caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to the absence of one X chromosome. This genetic abnormality is commonly associated with infertility, short stature, webbed neck, and a variety of other clinical features.

 

Turner syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea due to ovarian dysgenesis (underdeveloped ovaries), which leads to hormonal imbalances that prevent normal menstruation and fertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: Down syndrome, or trisomy 21, is characterized by an extra chromosome 21, resulting in 47 chromosomes. It is associated with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and other health complications, not infertility related to the absence of an X chromosome.

 

Option C. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with a 47, XXY karyotype. Patients typically have an extra X chromosome and may present with infertility, gynecomastia, and tall stature. It does not occur in females and does not present as 45, XO.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18, is characterized by an extra chromosome 18, leading to 47 chromosomes. It presents with severe developmental delays and congenital abnormalities. It is unrelated to the XO karyotype seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, XO karyotype, where there is a complete or partial absence of the second X chromosome, leading to infertility, primary amenorrhea, and other characteristic features.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.

 

Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.

 

Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles)

 

Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection: Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Isolate for 6 days

 

The given scenario points to the diagnosis of chickenpox.

 

In a boys' hostel, everyone is not in the high-risk groups for severe varicella infection. For the management of suspected cases in this situation, isolation for 6 days from the onset of the rash is the appropriate measure to prevent further spread of the infection. Acyclovir and ZIG are not necessary for healthy individuals.

 

Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is indicated as prophylaxis for individuals at high risk like Immunocompromised individuals, Pregnant women and Newborns.

 

 

 

Note –

 

Acyclovir: Antiviral treatment with acyclovir is generally reserved for high-risk groups or severe cases.

 

VZIG (Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin): VZIG is indicated for individuals at high risk of severe varicella infection, such as immunocompromised individuals, pregnant women, and newborns. It is not routinely given to healthy individuals in a setting like a boys' hostel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing a chickenpox outbreak in a boys' hostel, the best step is to isolate affected individuals for 6 days from the onset of the rash. This helps prevent the spread of the virus. Antiviral treatments and immunoglobulins are reserved for high-risk individuals.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise.  There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

 

The presence of recurrent deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise) in a male is suggestive of a clotting factor deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency: Typically presents with mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time, not deep tissue bleeding as described.

 

Option C. Lupus anticoagulant: Usually associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to a paradoxical increase in thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option D. Factor 9/12 deficiency: Factor XII deficiency does not cause significant bleeding and is usually discovered incidentally with prolonged aPTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which of the following is the most likely primary cause? (NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

 

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph node is most commonly caused by the anal canal below the dentate line (which marks the border between the anal canal and rectum) goes into the inguinal lymph nodes. As a result, anal cancer occurring below the dentate line can lead to the enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes.

 

However, lymphatics from the anal canal above the dentate line (i.e., the rectum) drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

 

Anal Cancer:  A malignancy that originates in the anal canal or anal margin.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage from the anal canal is to the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, an enlarged inguinal lymph node can indicate the spread of a tumor from the anal region.
  • Clinical Relevance: Patients with anal cancer may present with anal bleeding, pain, or itching. Inguinal lymph node enlargement is an important sign to check for, as it indicates lymphatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the testes.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Therefore, testicular tumors typically spread first to these nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While testicular cancer can metastasize to the inguinal lymph nodes, it's an unusual pathway and typically occurs after a surgical procedure in the groin, which can disrupt the typical lymphatic drainage patterns.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Colon Cancer: Malignancy that arises from the sigmoid portion of the colon.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the sigmoid colon is to the colic nodes and then to the inferior mesenteric nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Inguinal lymph node enlargement is not a typical early site of metastasis for sigmoid colon cancer. More common metastatic sites include the liver and lungs.

 

Option D. Prostate Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the prostate gland.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the prostate is to the internal iliac lymph nodes and then to the external iliac nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While it's possible for prostate cancer to metastasize to the inguinal nodes, it's not the typical pattern of lymphatic spread. Symptoms of prostate cancer include urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type III

 

The classification of achalasia into types I, II, and III is based on the Chicago Classification. This system uses high-resolution manometry to categorize esophageal motility disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Telogen effluvium

 

  • The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium.
  • The condition described is characterized by the sudden onset of scalp hair loss, typically occurring one to two months after a triggering event, which may include high fever, infections (such as Cholera, Typhoid, or COVID-19), surgery, trauma, starvation, myocardial infarction (MI), pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • This type of hair loss is associated with an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to the premature termination of the anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of significant stress.
  • When telogen hair shedding lasts for more than six months, it is termed “chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.” The main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss include thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgenetic alopecia: Typically presents as a patterned hair loss and is more gradual. It is driven by genetic factors and hormonal influences and does not usually have a sudden onset associated with illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata:

  • An autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks hair follicles.
  • It results in small, round, and smooth patches of hair loss, which can coalesce but often do not cause complete hair loss.

 

 

  • It's not directly linked to illnesses like COVID-19 and does not typically present as diffuse hair loss across the entire scalp as suggested in the question.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania:

  • A psychological condition where individuals compulsively pull out their own hair, leading to hair loss.
  • Hair loss pattern tends to be irregular with varied length hairs, and examination often reveals broken hairs.

 

 

 

  • The history provided does not suggest any compulsive behavior or the typical patchy, irregular pattern seen with trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 387

questions.text: According to World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VA < 3/60

 

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This definition has been in place since 2017 and has also been adopted by India’s National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). The definition includes three criteria, any of which can classify a person as blind:

 

  1. Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best correction possible
  2. Visual field less than 10 degrees
  3. Inability to count fingers at 3 meters

 

Note – VA < 6/60 was the old Indian criteria for blindness before 2017, where visual acuity less than 6/60 and visual field less than 20 degrees were considered blind. However, this is no longer the current WHO or Indian standard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO definition of blindness, adopted since 2017, is visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best possible correction, or visual field less than 10 degrees, or inability to count fingers at 3 meters.

questions.text: 15-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. CRP and ESR were elevated, and urinalysis showed RBCs. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgA vasculitis

 

IgA vasculitis, formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes. It commonly presents in children and young adults with a classic tetrad of symptoms: palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis or arthralgia, and renal involvement (hematuria). The elevated CRP and ESR indicate an inflammatory process, and the presence of RBCs in the urine suggests renal involvement, all of which are consistent with IgA vasculitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis: This condition, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a type of vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels and is characterized by granulomas, often affecting the respiratory tract and kidneys. It does not typically present with palpable purpura.

 

Option C. Microscopic polyangiitis: This is another small-vessel vasculitis that can present with renal involvement and systemic symptoms, but it does not typically present with palpable purpura and is not specifically associated with IgA deposition.

 

Option D. Behçet's disease: Behçet's disease is a vasculitis that can affect vessels of all sizes and presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. Palpable purpura and the specific symptom triad in this case are not characteristic of Behçet's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) commonly presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and renal involvement, and is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed to have CFTR gene mutations. What is the defective channel? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cl

 

Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) gene mutations lead to defective chloride channels. The CFTR protein regulates the transport of chloride ions across epithelial cell membranes. In cystic fibrosis, mutations in the CFTR gene result in dysfunctional chloride channels, leading to the production of thick, sticky mucus. This thick mucus can cause various problems, including chronic respiratory infections, pancreatic enzyme insufficiency, and other complications.

 

The defective chloride channels are the underlying cause of the clinical manifestations seen in cystic fibrosis, as they disrupt the normal movement of chloride and sodium ions in and out of cells, thereby affecting the hydration and viscosity of secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na:  Sodium channels are not primarily affected by CFTR mutations. Although sodium transport can be indirectly affected due to the dysfunction in chloride transport, sodium channels themselves are not defective in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. K: Potassium channels are not involved in the pathophysiology of cystic fibrosis. The disease specifically involves chloride transport.

 

Option D. Ca:  Calcium channels are not affected by CFTR gene mutations. The defective channel in cystic fibrosis is specific to chloride ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride channels, which are responsible for the thick, sticky mucus characteristic of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely affected, based on the hand posture shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • Claw Hand deformity is a condition where the fingers are bent into a position that looks like a claw. 
  • It may affect all of the fingers or only some of them depending on its cause. 
  • Claw Hand is a hand deformity with hyperextension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. 
  • Claw Hand deformity can be complete when it involves all the digits due to both ulnar and median nerve palsy, or it can be incomplete/partial where it involves only ulnar 2 digits due to isolated ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Muscle wasting of the interrosseous and hypothenar
    • Numbness along the nerve involved
    • Inability to extend the IP joints during extension of the fingers, to abduct and adduct fingers
    • Unopposed action of the extensors and the flexors digitorum profundus as the lumbricals of digits 4 and 5 are paralyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: Compression, stretch, or traumatic disruption of the nerve may result in median nerve palsies. Most commonly, palsies of the median nerve are caused by compression at the carpal tunnel, known as carpal tunnel syndrome. Women have 3 times higher incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome compared to men. It peaks around age 50 but also frequently present in the older population. Patients with diabetes and thyroid disease are at an increased risk for carpal tunnel syndrome. With carpal tunnel syndrome, weakness in the thenar eminence is observed. Isolation of the opponens pollicis power is done by asking the patient to palmarly abduct the thumb. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: Isolated injuries of the Musculocutaneous Nerve are rare. It may become injured by brachial Plexus damage, compression injury, dislocation of the shoulder, shoulder surgery, or entrapment of the nerve at the elbow. Most significant is the entrapment of the musculocutaneous nerve within the coracobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis weakness and atrophy with accompanying loss of sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4th and 5th digits. 
  • This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. 
  • Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text:
To study the effect of Vitamin C consumption on the occurrence of Respiratory disease, arrange the steps of a case-control study in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]


1 – Measurement of exposure.
2 – Matching.
3 – Analysis and interpretation.
4 – Selection of cases and controls.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4-2-1-3

 
A case-control study is a retrospective observational study design commonly used to investigate the causes of a condition or disease. The steps are as follows:

 

4. Selection of cases and controls : The first step involves identifying the cases (individuals with the disease) and controls (individuals without the disease). In this example, cases would be people with respiratory disease, and controls would be those without it.

 

2. Matching : The next step is to match the cases and controls on various confounding factors such as age, gender, or lifestyle to minimize bias.

 

1. Measurement of exposure : After matching, the history of exposure to the risk factor (in this case, Vitamin C consumption) is measured for both cases and controls by collecting historical data.

 

3. Analysis and interpretation : Finally, data is analyzed, often using a 2x2 table to calculate the odds ratio, which determines the association between the exposure and the disease. An odds ratio greater than 1 indicates a positive association, less than 1 indicates a protective effect, and equal to 1 indicates no association.

 

Educational Objective:


The correct sequence of steps in a case-control study is: Selection of cases and controls, matching, measurement of exposure, and then analysis and interpretation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

 

  • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.

 

Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
