questions.text: In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a first-time pregnant woman visits a healthcare facility for her delivery following encouragement from an ASHA worker. What monetary advantages will they obtain under the Janani Suraksha Yojana? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA

 

Under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive scheme, pregnant women who deliver in healthcare facilities are provided financial assistance. The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

 

Madhya Pradesh is categorized as a Low Performing State (LPS), the incentives are as follows:

 

  • Mother's Package: ₹1000
  • ASHA's Package: ₹400

 

Educational Objective:  

 

 

(LPS: Low performing states; HPS: High performing states)

 

(LPS include UP, Uttarakhand, MP, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Jammu & Kashmir, Rajasthan)

choices.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal

questions.text: Why do neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

 

Warburg metabolism is used by neoplastic cells to generate metabolic intermediates required for cell growth and multiplication.

 

Even when there is plenty of oxygen available, cancer cells shift their glucose metabolism away from the oxygen-hungry but efficient mitochondria and towards glycolysis. This phenomenon is known as the Warburg effect, and it is also referred to as aerobic glycolysis.

 

This metabolic change is so common in tumors that some consider it the eighth cancer hallmark.

 

Even though the latter produces more ATP, cancer cells prefer glycolysis (2 ATP) to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (36 ATP) for glucose metabolism. It's because pure oxidative phosphorylation generates a lot of ATP while also converting glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties to use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.

 

For this reason, rapidly growing cells, by undergoing glycolysis, produce carbon moieties that are needed for growth and cellular maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells: Incorrect. The Warburg effect actually increases glucose uptake and utilization by cancer cells to meet their high metabolic demands.

 

Option C. It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production: Incorrect. Glycolysis produces less ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation. The advantage of the Warburg effect lies in providing metabolic intermediates, not in ATP production.

 

Option D. It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal: Incorrect. While cancer cells do evade apoptosis and become immortal, this is not the direct reason they utilize the Warburg effect. The Warburg effect primarily supports cell growth and multiplication through the generation of biosynthetic precursors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neoplastic cells utilize the Warburg metabolism to generate metabolic intermediates necessary for cell growth and multiplication. Despite being less efficient in ATP production, glycolysis provides carbon moieties needed for biosynthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, supporting rapid proliferation and cellular maintenance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent headaches, visual disturbances, and features of increased intracranial tension. CT imaging reveals a well-circumscribed brain lesion, and its biopsy shows psammoma bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meningioma

 

Meningioma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and histopathological findings. Meningiomas are typically well-circumscribed, slow-growing tumors arising from the arachnoid meningothelial cells. The hallmark histological finding of psammoma bodies—concentric rings of calcification—is characteristic of meningiomas. These tumors commonly present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure such as headaches and visual disturbances.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schwannoma: Incorrect. Schwannomas arise from Schwann cells of peripheral nerves or cranial nerves (most commonly CN VIII). They typically present with symptoms related to the affected nerve rather than generalized increased intracranial pressure. Histologically, they show Antoni A (hypercellular) and Antoni B (hypocellular) areas with Verocay bodies, not psammoma bodies.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: Incorrect. Medulloblastomas are aggressive, highly malignant tumors that primarily affect children and typically arise in the cerebellum. They present with cerebellar symptoms and features of increased intracranial pressure due to obstruction of CSF flow. Histologically, they show small round blue cells with Homer Wright rosettes, not psammoma bodies.

 

 

Option C. Ependymoma: Incorrect. Ependymomas arise from ependymal cells lining the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord. They typically occur in children and young adults, often presenting with hydrocephalus due to CSF obstruction. Microscopically, they show perivascular pseudorosettes and true ependymal rosettes, not psammoma bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningiomas are characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) on histopathological examination and typically present as well-circumscribed lesions causing symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A woman suffered from sunburn after enjoying a vacation on a beach. Now while taking a shower lukewarm water (40 degree celsiuis) touches her back causing her to feel pain. What type of receptors are activated by lukewarm water and what causes her to feel pain? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Innocuous thermal receptor - allodynia

 

After a sunburn, the skin becomes sensitive. When the patient takes a bath with 40-degree Celsius water, which is lukewarm and not hot, the warm sensation should not normally cause pain. This temperature is considered a non-painful, or innocuous, thermal stimulus. In this scenario, the innocuous thermal receptors, which usually respond to non-painful stimuli, are activated. However, due to the skin's heightened sensitivity after sunburn, this harmless stimulus results in a painful sensation. This phenomenon, where a normally non-painful stimulus causes pain, is known as allodynia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noxious thermal receptor - hyperalgesia: This would occur if a painful stimulus led to an exaggerated pain response. However, in this case, the stimulus (40-degree water) is not painful and hence does not activate noxious receptors.

 

Option C. Noxious thermal receptor - allodynia: Allodynia refers to pain resulting from a non-painful stimulus, but noxious receptors respond to painful stimuli. Therefore, this option is incorrect because it misidentifies the type of receptor involved.

 

Option D. Innocuous thermal receptor - hyperalgesia: Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated pain response to a painful stimulus. Since 40-degree water is not a painful stimulus, hyperalgesia is not applicable here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allodynia is a condition where a normally non-painful stimulus, such as lukewarm water, causes pain. This occurs due to the activation of innocuous thermal receptors in the setting of heightened skin sensitivity, such as after a sunburn.

questions.text: Leading questions can be allowed in? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross Examination

 

Explanation:

 

Leading questions (questions whose answers can be given in yes/no format) are specifically allowed in:

 

  1. Cross examination
  2. Dying deposition
     For example: "Has Ram killed Shyam?" is a leading question, while "Who killed Shyam?" is not This restriction helps ensure unbiased testimony during direct examination and re-examination​

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed in direct examination unless a witness becomes hostile

​

Option C. Re-Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not permitted unless required to clarify contradictions arising from cross-examination​

 

Option D. Any Time: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed freely in all legal proceedings. They are only allowed in cross-examination and dying depositions​

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leading questions 


Ans can be given in Yes/ No
E.g.,
Has Suresh killed Madan? – is a leading question 
Who killed Madan? - It is not a leading question
 

Leading Questions


When leading conditions can be asked

  1. Dying deposition 
  2. Cross examination 
  3. As an exception in Examination in chief if witness turns hostile

     

When leading questions cannot be asked 

  1. Dying declaration 
  2. Examination in chief 
  3. Re – examination

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: What renal function does the formula UV/P represent? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

Renal clearance is a measure of the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. It provides important information about the efficiency with which the kidneys can filter out a substance from the bloodstream and excrete it in the urine.

 

The formula is:

 

Clearance(C) = UV /P ​

 

Where:

 

  • C is the clearance of the substance.
  • U is the concentration of the substance in the urine.
  • V is the urine flow rate (volume of urine produced per unit time).
  • P is the concentration of the substance in the plasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration fraction: This is the ratio of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) to the renal plasma flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This refers to the active process by which substances are transported from the blood into the renal tubule. While clearance can involve secretion, the formula UV/P specifically calculates overall clearance, not just secretion.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This refers to the process by which substances are reabsorbed from the renal tubule back into the blood. The UV/P formula does not directly represent reabsorption but overall clearance, which can include filtration and reabsorption processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the renal clearance of a substance, reflecting the volume of plasma from which the kidneys can completely remove that substance per unit time.

choices.text: It is mostly in children
It can be associated with MEN 2A

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about a patient with a retroperitoneal mass, episodic hypertension, palpitations, and increased urinary VMA levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It can be associated with MEN 2A

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor that typically presents with episodic hypertension, palpitations, headaches, and elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) levels.

 

Pheochromocytomas are known to be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A), which involves mutations in the RET gene. Patients with MEN 2A often present with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

 

Remember – The genes associated with pheochromocytoma, includes the RET gene, P53 gene, VHL gene, and the succinate dehydrogenase B (SDHB) gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are more common in adults, and only about 10% of cases occur in children. Therefore, this statement is incorrect as the majority of cases are found in adults.

 

Option B. It is usually malignant: Pheochromocytomas are benign in about 90% of cases. Malignancy is seen in only about 10% of cases, so this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. It is mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are predominantly unilateral. Bilateral tumors are seen in only 10% of cases, often in familial syndromes such as MEN 2A. Hence, this statement is not accurate for the majority of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors associated with episodic hypertension and increased urinary VMA levels. They are commonly linked with MEN 2A syndrome, which involves RET gene mutations.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray was done, as shown below. Identify the bowel segment involved? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Jejunum

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of intestinal obstruction where the involved segment is the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes (complete mucosal folds), indicating jejunal involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Ileum: Typically, ileal loops are located more peripherally and may show less prominent valvulae conniventes.

 

Option. C. Duodenum: Not usually seen as prominently distended in obstructions due to its fixed retroperitoneal location and smaller length.

 

Option. D. Transverse colon: Would generally show haustrations (sacculations) rather than valvulae conniventes, and distension would be more peripherally located.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Filiform

 

The filiform papillae are the most numerous of the lingual papillae on the tongue, but they do not contain taste buds. They are primarily responsible for the general sensations of touch, temperature, pressure, and texture. Unlike other types of papillae—such as foliate, fungiform, and circumvallate—filiform papillae are not involved in the sensation of taste, which is a special sensory function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foliate: These papillae are located on the lateral sides of the tongue and contain taste buds. They are primarily involved in sensing sweet and sour tastes.

 

Option C. Fungiform Papilla: These are found on the top of the tongue and are involved in sensing sweet, sour, and salty tastes. They contain taste buds.

 

Option D. Circumvallate: These are located at the back of the tongue and are primarily involved in sensing bitter tastes. They also contain taste buds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest time when triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining can detect changes after a myocardial infarction? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2-3 hours

 

Triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining is used for the gross assessment of myocardial infarction. TTC reacts with the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) enzyme present in viable cardiac myocytes, producing a brick-red color in normal, viable myocardium. In infarcted areas, where the LDH enzyme has leaked out of damaged cells into the bloodstream, the tissue remains unstained (pale or white). This change can be detected as early as 2-3 hours after infarction, making it one of the earliest gross diagnostic methods for myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. By 6-12 hours, TTC staining would already show clear evidence of infarction. This timeframe is too late to be considered the earliest time for detection using TTC staining.

 

Option C. 12-24 hours: Incorrect. At this stage, myocardial infarction would show extensive changes on TTC staining, with well-defined areas of pallor representing infarcted tissue. This is well beyond the earliest detection time.

 

Option D. After 24 hours: Incorrect. This represents a late stage in the evolution of myocardial infarction, when multiple other changes including coagulative necrosis and inflammatory cell infiltration are occurring. TTC staining can detect changes much earlier than this timeframe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) staining can detect myocardial infarction changes as early as 2-3 hours post-infarction by identifying areas where LDH enzyme has leaked from damaged cardiac cells.

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Homonymous hemianopia

 

The image shows a visual field defect characterized by loss of vision on the right side of the visual field in both eyes, which is termed as homonymous hemianopia. The term "homonymous" indicates that the defect is on the same side of the visual field in both eyes, while "hemianopia" refers to the loss of half of the visual field.

 

This pattern is typically caused by a lesion in the left optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe, which affects the visual field on the opposite side (right side in this case). The defect is contralateral to the side of the lesion, meaning that a left-sided lesion will produce a right-sided visual field loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopia: This condition involves the loss of vision in the temporal (outer) fields of both eyes, usually due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, such as from a pituitary tumor. The image does not show this pattern, as only the right visual fields are affected, not the outer fields.

 

Option B. Binasal hemianopia: This defect involves the loss of vision in the nasal (inner) fields of both eyes, often resulting from bilateral optic nerve compression. The visual defect in the image does not match this pattern, as it shows only right-sided field loss.

 

Option C. Altitudinal defect: This type of defect affects the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes, commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy. The image does not depict an upper or lower field defect; rather, it shows a loss on the right side of both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text: A patient presented with tingling and numbness in the legs, polyuria, and weight loss. He underwent a bone marrow aspirate (image as shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma with renal involvement

 

The bone marrow aspirate image shows numerous plasma cells with eccentric nuclei, which is a hallmark of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow.

 

Patients often present with symptoms such as polyuria, weight loss, and neuropathy due to the disease's impact on the kidneys and bones. The presence of more than 10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, renal involvement is common in multiple myeloma due to the deposition of monoclonal light chains, contributing to the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  SACD due to diabetes: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) in the context of diabetes would involve neuropathy, but it would not lead to the significant increase in plasma cells seen on the bone marrow aspirate. Bone marrow biopsy is not typically indicated in diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option B. SACD with B12 deficiency: This condition leads to neurological symptoms like tingling and numbness but usually presents with megaloblastic anemia rather than increased plasma cells. It does not explain the bone marrow findings or the systemic symptoms of polyuria and weight loss.

 

Option D. Metastasis: Metastatic disease can affect the bone marrow but would not typically present with a significant number of plasma cells with eccentric nuclei as seen in multiple myeloma. Additionally, the systemic symptoms and bone marrow findings align more closely with multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is identified by an increase in clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, accompanied by systemic symptoms such as renal involvement, neuropathy, and weight loss.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. Her ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm, consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Her blood pressure is stable. What is the first-line drug of choice for treating this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine

 

Explanation:

 

In a hemodynamically stable patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment after attempting vagal maneuvers.

 

Adenosine is preferred because:

 

  • Extremely short half-life (8-10 seconds)
  • Effectively terminates most forms of SVT by blocking AV nodal conduction
  • Administered as a rapid IV push (6 mg initial dose, followed by 12 mg if needed)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Not first-line therapy for acute SVT. More commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias or refractory SVT

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Effective for rate control in AF, but not the first choice for acute SVT termination

 

Option D. Verapamil: Used for SVT treatment, but not first-line due to risk of hypotension and bradycardia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), administered as a rapid IV push following vagal maneuvers.

questions.text: An epileptic patient presents with gum hypertrophy and bleeding. Which antiepileptic drug is the likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

 

Explanation:

 

Phenytoin is known to cause gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and bleeding as adverse effects. The adverse effects of phenytoin can be remembered using the mnemonic 

 

"HOT MALIKA":

 

H: Hirsutism and Hypertrophy of gums

O: Osteomalacia

T: Teratogenicity (fetal hydantoin syndrome)

M: Megaloblastic anemia (due to folate deficiency)

A: Arrhythmias (in overdose)

L: Lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy)

I: Inhibition of insulin secretion (can lead to hyperglycemia)

K: Vitamin K deficiency (can result in bleeding)

A: Ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo (cerebellar side effects in overdose)

 

The gum hypertrophy is a direct effect of phenytoin on gingival tissue, while the bleeding is due to vitamin K deficiency caused by phenytoin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: 

 

Valproate's adverse effects include 

 

V - Vomiting

A - Alopecia/Curling of hair

L - Liver disease (hepatotoxicity: in young children has high incidence)

P - Pancreatitis, ↑ risk of PCOD (gender Specific S/E)

R - Rash, allergy

O - Obesity

A - Ataxia (in overdose)

TE - Teratogenicity (most teratogenic Antiepileptic drug)

 

Therefore, if administered during pregnancy, a high dose of folic acid (4000μg/day) should be supplemented to prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine: 

 

Carbamazepine's adverse effects can be remembered as "4 A's":

 

  • Auto-induction (increases metabolism of itself and other drugs)
  • Aplastic anemia (bone marrow suppression)
  • ADH release (which can cause SIADH and dilutional hyponatremia)
  • Ataxia/nystagmus/vertigo (in overdose)

 

It does not cause gum hypertrophy or vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding.

 

Option D. Ethosuximide: Ethosuximide primarily affects T-type calcium channels and is used mainly for absence seizures. Its adverse effects are relatively mild compared to other antiepileptics and do not include gum hypertrophy or bleeding. The main side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances and CNS effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenytoin causes gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding as characteristic adverse effects, which can be remembered using the mnemonic 

 

"HOT MALIKA."

 

Adverse Effects 

 

H - Hirsutism, Hypertrophy of gums 

O-Osteomalacia 

T- Teratogenicity [Fetal Hydantoin syndrome] 

M - Megaloblastic Anemia [↓ Folate] 

A- Arrhythmia [Only in overdose] 

L- Lymph node enlargement 

I - ↓Insulin (avoided in DM) 

K-↓ Vitamin K 

A - Ataxias, vertigo [cerebellar symptoms] only at high dose]

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/O unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chancroid

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes). The history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the clinical presentation of painful genital ulcers and painful lymph nodes strongly suggest chancroid.

 

  1. Painful genital ulcers: Chancroid typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitalia. These ulcers can be multiple and have irregular, undermined edges.
  2. Painful lymph nodes: The infection often leads to painful, swollen lymph nodes in the inguinal region, which can sometimes suppurate and form buboes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily, not typically associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Chancre: A chancre is a painless ulcer that is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It does not fit the description of painful ulcers and painful lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Herpes: Genital herpes, caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), presents with painful vesicles that evolve into ulcers. However, the presence of vesicles, rather than ulcers initially, distinguishes herpes from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

 

Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

 

In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).

 

It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid resistant glomerulonephritis: This term is more of a clinical description rather than a specific pathological diagnosis. Steroid-resistant cases can include various glomerulonephritis types such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also shows podocyte effacement but is not the classic example of it.

 

Option C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is associated with severe glomerular damage and rapid loss of kidney function. It does not specifically show effacement of podocyte foot processes as its primary feature.

 

Option D. Chronic glomerulonephritis: Chronic glomerulonephritis encompasses various forms of long-standing glomerular diseases leading to chronic kidney damage. It is associated with glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis but not specifically with podocyte foot process effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia, who did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine, was started on drug A. After beginning treatment with drug A, the patient's psychotic symptoms improved; however, he developed sialorrhea, dyslipidemia, weight gain, and hyperglycemia. Which drug is most likely to be 'drug A'? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clozapine

 

The description of the patient's response and side effects suggests that 'drug A' is most likely Clozapine. Clozapine is known for its effectiveness in treatment-resistant schizophrenia, where other antipsychotics like haloperidol and thioridazine have failed. It is distinguished by its side effect profile, which includes sialorrhea (excessive salivation), significant weight gain, dyslipidemia (abnormal lipid levels), and hyperglycemia (high blood sugar). These side effects are more pronounced with Clozapine compared to other antipsychotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ziprasidone: While it is an atypical antipsychotic, Ziprasidone is less likely to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects compared to Clozapine.

 

Option C. Risperidone: Risperidone can cause weight gain and metabolic side effects, but it is less likely to cause sialorrhea and is not as commonly used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia as Clozapine.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole is known for having a more favorable metabolic side effect profile and is less likely to cause significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia compared to Clozapine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of treatment-resistant schizophrenia, Clozapine is often effective where other antipsychotics have failed. However, its use is associated with notable side effects including sialorrhea, significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia.

 

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 222-224.

questions.text: What is the recommended dose of adrenaline for a child during cardiac arrest ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.01 mg/kg (1ml/kg of 1:10,000 solution)

 

The recommended dose of adrenaline (epinephrine) for a child during cardiac arrest is 0.01 mg/kg, using a 1:10,000 dilution. Adrenaline is a potent vasoconstrictor and inotrope, meaning it increases heart rate, myocardial contractility, and peripheral resistance, which are all necessary in a cardiac arrest situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: 0.1 mg/kg (1ml/kg of 1:1000 solution): This dose is incorrect for cardiac arrest and could be dangerous if administered. The 1:1000 solution of adrenaline is typically used for severe allergic reactions (anaphylaxis), not for cardiac arrest.

 

Option C: 0.001 mg/kg (1ml/kg of 1:1,00,000 solution): This dose is too low to be effective during cardiac arrest and does not match the recommended guidelines.

 

Option D: 0.5 mg/kg (1ml/kg of 1:2000 solution): This option is incorrect as it does not correspond to the recommended concentration or dose for adrenaline administration in pediatric cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct dose of adrenaline for a child during cardiac arrest is 0.01 mg/kg using a 1:10,000 solution.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

 

The image shows a blastocyst, which is a developmental stage formed on the 4th day of embryonic development. 

 

  • An outer cell mass (trophoblast) that appears as a single layer of cells forming the wall
  • An inner cell mass which will form the embryo proper
  • A fluid-filled cavity is clearly visible, which is characteristic of a blastocyst The blastocyst contains approximately 32 cells and is formed from the morula stage when fluid begins to accumulate between the cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morula: Incorrect because a morula is a solid ball of 16 cells without any cavity, formed on day 3 of development. The image clearly shows a cavity and cell differentiation.

 

Option C. Zygote: Incorrect because a zygote is a single cell formed by fusion of sperm and egg. The image shows multiple cells arranged in a specific pattern.

 

Option D. Gastrula: Incorrect because gastrula is a later stage of development after blastocyst, characterized by three germ layers. The image shows only two cell populations typical of a blastocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blastocyst is a key structure in early human development that forms around day 5 post-fertilization and is essential for implantation. It consists of a trophoblast and an inner cell mass, which give rise to the placenta and embryo, respectively.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with multiple injuries, which included a femur fracture as well. He developed confusion, dyspnea, and a rash over his body. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat embolism

 

  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

  • The diagnosis is considered usually after 48 hours. 

 

Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours think of it!

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. 

  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).

    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:

      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea

      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation

      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder

 

  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:

    • Fracture stabilization

    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:

      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)

      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)

  • Offset its effect by:

    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)

    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release

    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.

  • Treatment:

    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.

    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.

    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism. An air embolism occurs when air is admitted into the vascular system. It can occur iatrogenically via interventional procedures but has also been described as a complication from a blunt and penetrating trauma. The most important diagnostic criterion is the patient's history. The procedures that carry the greatest risk of air embolism are craniotomy in the sitting position, cesarean section, hip replacement, and cardiopulmonary bypass. If the patient is conscious, chest pain, dyspnea, headache, and confusion can all be symptoms. If the embolus is severe, cardiac ischemia, arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest can ensue. 

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism. Many PEs are likely undiagnosed. Most PEs originate as venous thromboembolisms (VTEs) in the lower extremities or pelvic veins. Less frequently, upper extremity thromboembolic events lead to PE. Major risk factors for thromboembolic events include recent immobilization, MI, CVA, surgery, and recent trauma. PE may be asymptomatic or present with sudden death. Characteristic signs and symptoms such as tachycardia, dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxemia, and shock are non-specific. 

 

Option D. DIC. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a hypercoagulable state that can lead to both microvascular and macrovascular clotting and compromised blood flow, ultimately resulting in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. It typically occurs as an acute complication in patients with underlying life-threatening illnesses such as severe sepsis, hematologic malignancies, severe trauma, or placental abruption. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with fracture of femur, complaint of breathlessness after 48 hours, is highly suggestive of fat embolism.

questions.text: Post-partum IUCD insertion can be inserted till? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48h

 

Postpartum IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is classified into early postpartum and late postpartum insertion.

 

  • Early Postpartum IUCD (PPIUCD): This can be further divided into:
     
    • Within 10 minutes of placental delivery: This is known as immediate PPIUCD insertion.
    • After 10 minutes but within 48 hours of delivery: This is still considered early postpartum insertion and can be performed either after vaginal delivery or during a cesarean section.
       

If the IUCD is not inserted within this 48-hour window, it cannot be inserted until after six weeks postpartum. This period between 48 hours and six weeks is a contraindicated window for IUCD insertion due to the increased risk of expulsion and complications.

 

  • Late Postpartum IUCD: This insertion is done after six weeks postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum. The period between 48 hours and six weeks is contraindicated for IUCD insertion.
